pageTitle: Serena Williams wins US Open final with three-set triumph over Victoria Azarenka - Just In - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {7416=It is Williams' second major of 2013 after winning the French Open back in June.}
textBeforeTable: Serena Williams - career Initially frustrated by swirling wind at Arthur Ashe Stadium and missed match points in the second set, Williams regained the momentum in the third to take the final 7-5, 6-7(8-6), 6-1 and propel her to a 17th grand slam title. It has been 14 years since Serena Williams won her first US Open but there was no hint of decline as the 31-year-old American outlasted Victoria Azarenka to claim her fifth US Open singles title on Monday (AEST). ABC News Serena Williams wins her fifth US Open Video 1:20 Sorry, this video has expired Updated Mon 9 Sep 2013, 3:23 PM AEST Serena Williams wins US Open final with three-set triumph over Victoria Azarenka Just In Change to standard view More > WWI Centenary Rural Subscribe Entertainment Upload Photos Video Live Streams Fact Check Sport Business Analysis & Opinion World Australia Just In Home ABC News Search
textAfterTable: Williams will be 32 later this month but she seems far from even contemplating life after tennis. "I feel great. I have never felt better. I feel really fit," she said. "I can play a tournament like this, singles, doubles, with tough, tough schedules. For the most part, I felt really good. "I haven't felt like this in a number of years. I'm excited about the possibilities. I don't know what can happen. I just keep playing and do the best that I can." Certainly Azarenka, who put up a brave fight throughout and looks the most likely to take over Williams' mantle whenever she does retire, had no doubts about the quality of her opponent. "She's a champion, and she knows how to repeat that. She knows what it takes to get there," said the Belarusian. "I think it's incredible what she's achieving. She's playing definitely her best tennis right now. It is just really exciting for me to be able to compete against that type of player who can be the greatest of all time." It is Williams' second major of 2013 after winning the French Open back in June. The 31-year-old now has five Australian Opens, five Wimbledon crowns and two French Opens, in addition to her New York victories. Photo On top ... Serena Williams celebrates during the first set
